Award.AwardTitle: Nano Ferrous Particles Dispersed on Optical Fiber Sensors for Distributed Corrosion Assessment of Civil Infrastructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this award is to explore and create a distributed corrosion monitoring system with multiplexed long period fiber grating sensors that will be packaged with nano ferrous particles filled polymers. The change in wavelength of the fiber gratings is related to the degree of corrosion in the ferrous particles through effective refractive index of the packaged optical fiber. The approach is to develop rugged sensors and deploy them in parallel with corrosion susceptible components (for example, steel beams and reinforcing bars), accurately quantify the corrosion rate and mass loss of ferrous particles in the well-controlled sensor structure, causatively relate the corrosion data from the sensors to their nearby steel components, and cost-effectively assess both pit and uniform corrosion induced deteriorations of the steel components and then the load capacity of their structural system.

Once validated and implemented in bridge applications, the proposed corrosion sensors could impact the maintenance and safety of transportation infrastructures. They have the potential to save up to $8 per square foot of bridge decks in the case that the bridge decks are monitored and determined to have an extra year of service. Their outcomes (corrosion rate and mass loss) can be directly used in bridge design and management, thus realizing both short- and long-term benefits. The research findings will be disseminated through technical publications, international workshops, and exchange visits with other peer institutions. Two lecture modules on "corrosion phenomenon" and "assessment tool" will be developed and used in all education and outreach activities. Underrepresented students will directly participate in this project and get trained with such a highly interdisciplinary research topic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

This project enabled the exploration and development of new concepts in three categories: (1) ferrous particles coated long period fiber gratings (LPFG) as wavelength-based sensors, (2) turn-around-point LPFG as intensity-based sensors, and (3) coax cables as Fabry-Perot interferometer.

Ferrous Particles on Wavelength-based LPFG Sensors Nano iron and silica particles were mixed with polyurethane and coated in approximately 3.5 µm on LPFG sensors. The iron particles were corroded at a sensitivity of 0.0373 mm/year. To improve the coating uniformity, an LPFG sensor was deposited with an inner layer of silver (for its conductivity) and then electroplated with an outer layer of Fe-C (as a corrosion medium). Given an Ag film of 0.8 μm thick, the change in resonant wavelength of three sensors decreased from 0.23 nm to approximately 0.15 nm per 1% corrosion mass loss of the Fe-C coating that was originally set to 8 μm to 20 μm thick. When the Ag film became 1.2 μm thick, the effect of the Fe-C thickness on the LPFG sensitivity was negligible. The service life of the sensors increased with the thickness of either Ag film or Fe-C coating, which is a trade-off of the sensitivity of the sensors unless the Ag film is 1.2 μm thick. The sensors can be used to predict the 60~90% mass loss of the Fe-C coating. To improve its transparency, the silver layer was replaced by graphene and nano silver wires. A graphene layer of approximately 1 nm thick was adhered to the curve surface of optical fiber under atmospheric pressure at low temperature in order to preserve structural integrity of the fiber and functionality of the LPFG. Compared to silver or other metal substrates, the graphene layer has superior optical transparency that increases the sensitivity (75%-95%) and service life (30%) of corrosion sensors.

Intensity-based LPFG Sensors The transmission power of a turn-around point LPFG linearly changed with refractive index surrounding the sensor. The LPFG sensors were demonstrated for the detection of sucrose solutions, refractive index matching liquids and low concentration glucose solutions. The response of the sensor in glucose concentration was quite linear with a detection sensitivity of approximately 2.65×10-4/mMol.

Coax-cable Fabry-Perot Interferometry A small section of the polymer dielectric material in a semi-rigid coax cable was replaced with a porous dielectric material. The outer conductor was perforated with a conformal coating so that moisture or liquid can seep through the outer conductor. As the two conductors corroded from the surfaces in direct contact with the dielectric material, a layer of partial dielectric was formed. The permittivity and permeability of the layer influenced the behavior of the electromagnetic wave that transmits in the cable.

Broader Impact

Once implemented in bridge applications, the Fe-C coated and tube encapsulated corrosion sensors will have profound impact on the transportation infrastructure maintenance and safety since $8/ft2 saving for each year that the lifespan of a bridge is extended can be achieved according to Federal Highway Administration. The developed corrosion sensors can also prevent the potential collapse of structures with embedded reinforcing steel.

The developed corrosion sensors advance the research instrumentation and infrastructure to deal with corrosion-related issues. The unique distributed corrosion sensors not only add one more device to the existing corrosion measurement toolbox, but also enable a direct assessment of mass loss of steel that is ultimately needed for bridge ratings in practice. Once applied, the new capability will change engineers’ perception and be more receptive about structural health monitoring since its outcomes can be directly used in bridge management and their benefits can be quantified and expected in the near future.

This project resulted in 1 provisional patent application, 8 journal papers, 2 conference papers, 5 invited/keynote presentations at international conferences, one Ph.D. dissertation (Yizheng Chen) completed, and another Ph.D. dissertation (Chuanrui Guo) in progress. It provided interdisciplinary training (civil engineering and chemistry) for at least four Ph.D. students (Yizheng Chen, Chuanrui Guo, Adrian Fetene, and Yang Song) and one postdoctoral fellow (Dr. Fujian Tang). Two of the Ph.D. students are female.

Data Management

Transmission spectra, the resonant wavelengths, and intensity of LPFG sensors were recorded from the sensors alone, coated sensors, and the sensors embedded in mortar and concrete. The resonant wavelength was related to the corrosion rate/mass loss of nano ferrous particles or Fe-C coating. Finally, the mass losses between nano ferrous particles/Fe-C coating and steel structures/rebar were correlated experimentally.
